Comment: >Weakening travel demand, signaled by grim earnings forecasts of travel-related companies, may erase billions of dollars from the U.S. economy this year as the Trump administration's trade policy takes a toll on consumer sentiment, analysts have warned."  >Anti-American sentiment could be driving a decline in international tourism, which is considered a service export," J.P.Morgan said in a note last week.  >Goldman Sachs and J.P.Morgan projected lower foreign travel spending to trim 0.1% from U.S. GDP this year, adding that the hit could be as much as 0.2% to 0.3%.  >As of the first quarter of 2025, U.S. GDP stands at $23.53 trillion, according to LSEG data, and the impact could amount to anywhere between $23 billion and $71 billion, based on Reuters calculations.  >"Tariff announcements and a more aggressive stance toward historical allies have hurt global opinions about the United States. The bigger issue is a pullback in tourist visits to the U.S.," Goldman Sachs said in March, at a time when Europeans were already [booking fewer trips](https://www.reuters.com/world/some-europeans-reconsider-trips-us-protest-against-trump-2025-03-24/) to the country.  >President Donald Trump's erratic tariffs have also led to global consumers [boycotting and ditching](https://www.reuters.com/world/europe/danes-boycotting-us-products-like-coca-cola-carlsberg-says-2025-04-29/) U.S. products and brands.
Author: YesterShill

Comment: As an American It amazes me how many people wanted to come here on vacation in the first place.  With the exception of a few major cities like Vegas, or NYC, and unusual places like Hawaii or Alaska, there's not much worth flying across the world for over here.  I live outside of D.C. right now. Huge tourist spot, but the reality is, outside of the museums and the historic government buildings that everyone knows, it's just a regular ass city. Not even particularly nice. Go to Paris instead, they got cooler stuff to see over there.

Comment: Cheaper tickets are good, but the weaker dollar hurts.  On Jan 19th, 1 dollar would get me 155 yen.  Today I get 143.  That means Hotels, food, and everything you buy is now 10% more expensive.  So even if the flight is a bit cheaper, the vacation isn't.

Comment: The US has lots of amazing places to visit! Our national parks for one (until Trump sells them to the highest bidder). The Grand Canyon, Brice, Yellowstone, etc are places that I would fly across the world to visit. This is a big country with a lot of stuff to see.  That said, If I lived in another country, I wouldn't visit the US for at least another 4 years.
Author: Professional-Can1385

Comment: The US has some amazing national parks and vistas, like Yellowstone or the Grand Canyon. Florida and California are a major destination for travellers looking to get some sun. Events like Mardi Gras, Burning Man, Coachella have international pull as well. People also have varied interests that can drive them to places like Hollywood, Roswell, Nashville, or to places where their favourite artist is currently touring.  There are plenty of reasons to go, but the current administration seems intent on supplying more and more reasons not to.
